editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The witch of Edmonton: a known true story.
Composed into a tragicomedy by divers well-esteemed poets; William Rowley, Thomas Dekker, John ford, etc.
Acted by the prince's servants, often at the cockpit in drury-lane, once at court, with singular applause.
London, printed by J. Cottrel, for Edward Blackmore, at the angel in Paul's churchyard. 1658.

div.head: The whole argument is this distich.
div.l: Forced marriage, murder; murder, blood requires:
Reproach, revenge; revenge, hell's help desires.

lg.l: The town of Edmonton hath lent the stage
A devil and a witch, both in an age.
To make comparisons it were uncivil,
Between so even a pair, a witch and devil.
But as the year doth with his plenty bring
As well a latter as a former spring;
So has this witch enjoyed the first, and reason
Presumes she may partake the other season:
In acts deserving name, the proverb says,
Once good, and ever; why not so in plays?
Why not in this? since (Gentlemen) we flatter
No expectation: here is mirth and matter.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Come, wench; why here's a business soon dispatched.
Thy heart I know is now at ease: thou needst not
Fear what the tattling gossips in their cups
Can speak against thy fame: thy child shall know
Who to call dad now.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: You have discharged the true part of an honest man;
I cannot request a fuller satisfaction
Than you have freely granted: yet methinks
'Tis an hard case, being lawful man and wife,
We should not live together.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Had I failed
In promise of my truth to thee, we must
Have then been ever sundered; now the longest
Of our forbearing either's company,
Is only but to gain a little time
For our continuing thrift, that so hereafter
The heir that shall be born may not have cause
To curse his hour of birth, which made him feel
The misery of beggary and want;
Two devils that are occasions to enforce
A shameful end. My plots aim but to keep
My father's love.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: And that will be as difficult
To be preserved, when he shall understand
How you are married, as it will be now,
Should you confess it to him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Fathers are
Won by degrees, not bluntly as our masters,
Or wronged friends are: and besides, I'll use
such dutiful and ready means, that ere
He can have notice of what's past, th' inheritance
To which I am born heir, shall be assured:
That done, why let him know it; if he like it not,
Yet he shall have no power in him left
To cross the thriving of it.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: You who had
The conquest of my maiden-love, may easily
Conquer the fears of my distrust. And whither
Must I be hurried?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Prithee do not use
A word so much unsuitable to the constant
Affections of thy husband: thou shalt live
Near Waltham abbey, with thy uncle Selman:
I have acquainted him with all at large:
He'll use thee kindly: thou shalt want no pleasures,
Nor any other fit supplies whatever
Thou canst in heart desire.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: All these are nothing
Without your company.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Which thou shalt have
Once every month at least.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Once every month!
Is this to have an husband?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Perhaps oftener:
That's as occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Ay, ay, in case
No other beauty tempt your eye, whom you
Like better, I may chance to be remembered,
And see you now and then. Faith, I did hope
You'd not have used me so: 'tis but my fortune.
And yet, if not for my sake, have some pity
Upon the child I go with, that's your own.
And, less you'll be a cruel hearted father,
You cannot but remember that.
Heaven knows how.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: To quit which fear at once,
As by the ceremony late performed,
I plighted thee a faith, as free from challenge,
As any double thought; once more in hearing
Of heaven and thee, I vow, that never henceforth
Disgrace, reproof, lawless affections, threats,
Or what can be suggested 'gainst our marriage,
Shall cause me falsify that bridal-oath
That binds me thine. And, Winifrid, whenever
The wanton heat of youth by subtle baits
of beauty, or what woman's art can practise,
Draw me from only loving thee; let heaven
Inflict upon my life some fearful ruin.
I hope thou dost believe me.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Swear no more;
I am confirmed, and will resolve to do
What you think most behooveful for us.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Thus then; make thyself ready: at the furthest house
Upon the green, without the town, your uncle
Expects you. For a little time farewell.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Sweet,
We shall meet again as soon as thou canst possibly?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: We shall. One kiss. Away.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Frank Thorney.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.p: Alone? then must I tell thee in plain terms, thou hast wronged thy master's house basely and lewdly.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Your house, sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Yes, sir, if the nimble devil
That wantoned in your blood, rebelled against
All rules of honest duty. You might, sir,
Have found out some more fitting place then here,
To have built a stews in. All the country whispers
How shamefully thou hast undone a maid,
Approved for modest life, for civil carriage,
Till thy prevailing perjuries enticed her
To forfeit shame. Will you be honest yet?
Make her amends and marry her?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: So, sir,
I might bring both myself and her to beggary;
And that would be a shame worse than the other.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: You should have thought on this before, and then
Your reason would have overswayed the passion
Of your unruly lust. But that you may
Be left without excuse, to salve the infamy
Of my disgraced house, and 'cause you are
A gentleman, and both of you my servants,
I'll make the maid a portion.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: So you promised me
Before, in case I married her. I know
Sir Arthur Clarington deserves the credit
Report hath lent him; and presume you are
A debtor to your promise: but upon
What certainty shall I resolve? Excuse me
for being somewhat rude.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: 'Tis but reason.
Well Frank, what thinkst thou of 200 l.
And a continual friend?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Though my poor fortunes
Might happily prefer me to a choice
Of a far greater portion; yet to right
A wronged maid, and to preserve your favour,
I am content to accept your proffer.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Art thou?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Sir, we shall every day have need to employ
The use of what you please to give.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Thou shalt have't.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then I claim your promise.
We are man and wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Already?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: And more than so, I have promised her
Free entertainment in her uncle's house,
Near Waltham abbey, where she may securely
So journey, till time and my endeavours work
My father's love and liking.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Honest Frank.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I hope, sir, you will think I cannot keep her
Without a daily charge.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: As for the money,
'Tis all thine own; and though I cannot make thee
A present payment, yet thou shalt be sure
I will not fail thee.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: But our occasions.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.p: Nay, nay, talk not of your occasions, trust my bounty: it shall not sleep. Hast married her, i'faith Frank?
sp.l: 'Tis well, 'tis passing well: then Winifrid,
Once more thou art an honest woman. Frank,
Thou hast a jewel. Love her; she'll deserve it.
And when to Waltham?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: She is making ready.
Her uncle stays for her.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Most provident speed.
Frank, I will be friend, and such a friend.
Thou'lt bring her thither?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Sir, I cannot: newly
My father sent me word I should come to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Marry, and do: I know thou hast a wit
To handle him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I have a suit t'ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: What is't?
Any thing, Frank, command it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: That you'll please,
By letters to assure my father, that
I am not married.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Some one or other
Hath certainly informed him that I purposed
To marry Winifrid; on which he threatened
to disinherit me, to prevent it,
Lowly I crave your letters, which he seeing
Will credit; and I hope ere I return,
On such conditions as I'll frame, his lands
Shall be assured.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: But what is that to quit
My knowledge of the marriage?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Why you were not
A witness to it.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: I conceive: and then,
His land confirmed, thou wilt acquaint him thoroughly
With all that's past.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I mean no less.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Provided,
I never was made privy to it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Alas, sir,
Am I a talker?

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Draw thyself the letter,
I'll put my hand to it. I commend thy policy
Thou'rt witty, witty Frank; nay, nay, 'tis fit,
Dispatch it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I shall write effectually.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Go thy way cuckoo; have I caught the young man?
One trouble then is freed. He that will feast
At others cost, must be a bold faced guest.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I have heard the news, all now is safe.
The worst is past.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Thy lip, wench: I must bid
Farewell, for fashion's sake; but I will visit thee
Suddenly, girl. This was cleanly carried:
Ha! was't not win?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Then were my happiness,
That I in heart repent I did not bring him
The dower of a virginity. Sir, forgive me;
I have been much to blame. Had not my laundress
Given way to your immoderate waste of virtue,
You had not with such eagerness pursued
The error of your goodness.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Dear, dear win.
I hug this art of thine, it shows how cleanly
Thou canst beguile in case occasion serve,
To practise. It becomes thee, now we share
Free scope enough, without control or fear,
To interchange our pleasures; we will surfeit
In our embraces, wench. Come, tell me, when
Wilt thou appoint a meeting?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: What to do?

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Good, good, to con the lesson of our loves,
Our secret game.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: O blush to speak it further!
As you're a noble gentleman, forget
A sin so monstrous: 'tis not gently done,
To open a cured wound. I know you speak
For trial; troth you need not.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: I for trial?
Not I, by this good sunshine.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Can you name
That syllable of good, and yet not tremble,
To think to what a foul and black intent,
You use it for an oath? Let me resolve you,
If you appear in any visitation
That brings not with it pity for the wrongs
Done to abused Thorney, my kind husband;
If you infect mine ear with any breath
That is not thoroughly perfumed with sighs
For former deeds of lust: may I be cursed
Even in my prayers, when I vouchsafe
To see or hear you. I will change my life,
From a loose whore, to a repentant wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Wilt thou turn monster now? art not ashamed
After so many months to be honest at last?
Away, away, fie on't.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: My resolution
Is built upon a rock. This very day
Young Thorney vowed with oaths not to be doubted,
That never any change of love should cancel
The bonds in which we are to either bound,
Of lasting truth. And shall I then for my part
Unseel the sacred oath set on record
In heaven's book? Sir Arthur, do not study
To add to your lascivious lust, the sin
Of sacrilege: for if you but endeavour
By any unchaste word to tempt my constancy,
You strive as much as in you lies to ruin
A temple hallowed to the purity
Of holy marriage. I have said enough:
You may believe me.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Get you to your nunnery,
There freeze in your old cloister. This is fine.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Good angels guide me. Sir, you'll give me leave
To weep and pray for your conversion.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Yes, away to Waltham. Pox on your honesty.
Had you no other trick to fool me? Well,
You may want money yet.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: None that I'll send for
To you, for hire of a damnation.
When I am gone, think on my just complaint:
I was your devil, oh be you my saint!

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Go, go thy ways, as changeable a baggage
As ever cozened knight. I'm glad I'm rid of her.
Honest? marry hang her. Thorney is my debtor,
I thought to have paid him too: but fools have fortune.

sp.stage: Enter old Thorney, and old Carter.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: You offer Mr. Carter, like a gentleman,
I cannot find fault with it, 'tis so fair.

sp.speaker: O. Cart.
sp.p: No gentleman, ay, Mr. Thorney; spare the mastership, call me by my name, John Carter; master is a title my father, nor his before him, were acquainted with. Honest Hertforshire yeomen, such an one am I; my word and my deed shall be proved one at all times. I mean to give you no security for the marriage-money.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.p: How? no security? although it need not, so long as you live; yet who is he has surety of his life one hour? Men, the proverb says, are mortal: else, for my part, I distrust you not, were the sum double.

sp.speaker: O. Cart.
sp.p: Double, treble, more or less; I tell you, Mr. Thorney, I'll give no security. Bonds and bills are but tarriers to catch fools, and keep lazy knaves busy; my security shall be present payment. And we here, about Edmonton, hold present payment as sure as an alderman's bond in London, Mr. Thorney.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: I cry you mercy, sir, I understood you not.

sp.speaker: O. Cart.
sp.p: I like young Frank well, so does my Susan too. The girl has a fancy to him, which makes me ready in my purse. There be other suitors within, that make much noise to little purpose. If Frank love sue, sue shall have none but Frank. 'tis a mannerly girl, Mr. Thorney, though but an homely man's daughter. There have worse faces looked out of black bags, man.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.p: You speak your mind freely and honestly. I marvel my son comes not: I am sure he will be here sometime today.

sp.speaker: O. Cart.
sp.p: Today or tomorrow, when he comes he shall be welcome to bread, beer and beef, yeoman's fare; we have no kickshaws: full dishes, whole bellyfuls. Should I diet three days at one of the slender city-suppers, you might send me to barber-surgeon's hall the fourth day, to hang up for an anatomy. — here come they that —

How now girls? every day playday with you? Enter Warbeck with Susan, Somerton with Katherine.Valentine's day too, all by couples? Thus will young folks do when we are laid in our graves, Mr. Thorney. Here's all the care they take. And how do you find the wenches, gentlemen? have they any mind to a loose gown and a straight shoe? Win 'em, and wear 'em. They shall choose for themselves by my consent.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.p: You speak like a kind father. Sue, thou hearest the liberty that is granted thee. What sayest thou? wilt thou be mine?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Your what, sir? I dare swear, never your wife.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.p: Canst thou be so unkind? considering how dear I affect thee; nay, dote on thy perfections.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: You are studied too scholarlike in words: I understand not. I am too course for such a gallants love as you are.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: By the honour of gentility.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Good sir, no swearing: yea and nay with us
Prevails above all oaths you can invent.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: By this white hand of thine.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Take a false oath? Fie, fie, flatter the wise: fools not regard it; and one of these am I.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: Dost thou despise me?

sp.speaker: O. Cart.
sp.p: Let 'em talk on, Mr. Thorney. I know Sue's mind. The fly may buzz about the candle, he shall but singe his wings when all is done. Frank, Frank is he has her heart.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: But shall I live in hope, Kate?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Better so, then be a desperate man.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Perhaps thou thinkst it is thy portion
I level at: wert thou as poor in fortunes,
As thou art rich in goodness; I would rather
Be suitor for the dower of thy virtues,
Then twice thy father is whole estate; and prithee
Be thou resolved so.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Mr. Somerton, it is an easy labour to deceive
A maid that will believe men's subtle promises:
Yet I conceive of you as worthily
As I presume you do deserve.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Which is
As worthily in loving thee sincerely,
As thou art worthy to be so beloved.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: I shall find time to try you.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Do, Kate, do:
And when I fail, may all my joys forsake me.

sp.speaker: O. Cart.
sp.p: Warbeck and Sue are at it still. I laugh to myself, Mr. Thorney, to see how earnestly he beats the bush, while the bird is flown into another's bosom. A very unthrift, Mr. Thorney; one of the country roaring lads: we have such as well as the city, and as arrant rake-hells as they are, though not so nimble at their prizes of wit. Sue knows the rascal to an hair's breadth, and will fit him accordingly.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: What is the other gentleman?

sp.speaker: O. Cart.
sp.p: One Somerton, the honester man of the two, by 5 l. in every stone-weight. A civil fellow. He has a fine convenient estate of land in Westham by Essex. m. Ranges that dwells by Enfield, sent him hither. He likes Kate well. I may tell you, I think she likes him as well. If they agree, I'll not hinder the match for my part. But that Warbeck is such another —. I use him kindly for Mr. Somerton's sake: for he came hither first as a companion of his. Honest men, Mr. Thorney, may fall into knave's company, now and then.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: Three hundred a year jointure, sue.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Where lies it, by sea or by land? I think by sea.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: Do I look like a captain?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Not a whit, sir.
Should all that use the seas be reckoned captains,
There is not a ship should have a scullion in her
To keep her clean.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: Do you scorn me, Mrs. Susan ▪
Am I a subject to be jeered at?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Neither
Am I a property for you to use
As stale to your fond wanton loose discourse.
Pray sir be civil.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: Wilt be angry, wasp?

sp.speaker: O. Cart.
sp.p: God-a-mercy, sue. She'll firk him on my life, if he fumble with her.
sp.l: Mr. Francis Thorney, you are welcome indeed.
sp.p: Your father expected your coming. How does the right worshipful knight, sir Arthur Clarington, your master?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: In health this morning. Sir, my duty.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: Now
You come as I could wish.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: Frank Thorney, ha!

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: You must excuse me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Virtuous. Mrs Susan.
Kind Mrs. Katherine. Gentlemen, to both
Good time o'th' day.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: The like to you.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: 'Tis he.
A word, friend. On my life, this is the man
Stands fair in crossing Susan's love to me.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: I think no less. Be wise, and take no notice on't.
He that can win her, best deserves her.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: Marry
A servingman? mew.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Prithee friend no more.

sp.speaker: O. Cart.
sp.p: Gentlemen all, there's within a slight dinner ready, if you please to taste of it: Mr. Thorney, Mr. Francis, Mr. Somerton. Why girls? what, huswives, will you spend all your forenoon in tittle-tattles? away: it's well i'faith. Will you go in, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: We'll follow presently: my son and I
Have a few words of business.

sp.speaker: O. Cart.
sp.l: At your pleasure.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: I think you guess the reason, Frank, for which
I sent for you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: I need not tell you.
With what a labyrinth of dangers daily
The best part of my whole estate's encumbered:
Nor have I any clew to wind it out,
But what occasion proffers me. Wherein
If you should falter, I shall have the shame,
And you the loss. On these two points rely
Our happiness or ruin. If you marry
With wealthy Carter's daughter, there's a portion
Will free my land: all which I will instate
Upon the marriage to you. Otherwise.
I must be of necessity enforced
To make a present sale of all: and yet,
For ought I know, live in as poor distress,
Or worse, than now I do. You hear the sum:
I told you thus before. Have you considered on't?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I have, sir. And however I could wish
To enjoy the benefit of single freedom,
for that I find no disposition in me
To undergo the burden of that care
That marriage brings with it; yet to secure
And settle the continuance of your credit,
I humbly yield to be directed by you
In all commands.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: You have already used
Such thriving protestations to the maid.
That she is wholly yours. And speak the truth,
You love her, do you not?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: 'Twere pity, sir,
I should deceive her.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: Better y' had been unborn.
But is your love so steady that you mean,
Nay, more, desire to make her your wife?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Else, sir,
It were a wrong not to be righted.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: True,
It were: and you will marry her?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Heaven prosper it:
I do intend it.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: O thou art a villain!
A devil like a man. Wherein have I
Offended all the powers so much, to be
Father to such a graceless godless son?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: To me, sir, this? O my cleft heart!

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: To thee,
Son of my curse. Speak truth, and blush, thou monster,
Hast thou not married Winifrid? A maid
Was fellow-servant with thee.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Some swift spirit
Has blown this news abroad. I must outface it.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: D'ye study for excuse? why all the country
Is full on't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: With your licence, 'tis not charitable,
I am sure it is not fatherly, so much
To be o'erswayed with credulous conceit
Of mere impossibilities. But fathers
Are privileged to think and talk at pleasure.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: Why canst thou yet deny thou hast no wife?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: What do you take me for? an atheist?
One that nor hopes the blessedness of life
Hereafter, neither fears the vengeance due
To such as make the marriage-bed an inn,
Which traveller's day and night,
After a toilsome lodging leave at pleasure?
Am I become so insensible of losing
The glory of creation's work? My soul!
O I have lived too long.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: Thou hast, dissembler;
Darest thou persevere yet? and pull down wrath
As hot as flames of hell, to strike thee quick
Into the grave of horror? I believe thee not.
Get from my sight.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Sir, though mine innocence
Needs not a stronger witness than the cleverness
Of an unperished conscience; yet for that
I was informed, how mainly you had been
Possessed of this untruth, to quit all scruple
Please you peruse this letter: 'tis to you.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: From whom?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Sir Arthur Clarington my master.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: On every side I am distracted: am waded deeper into mischief, than virtue can avoid. But on I must: fate leads me: I will follow. There you read what may confirm you.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.p: Yes, and wonder at it. Forgive me, Frank. Credulity abused me. My tears express my joy: and I am sorry I injured innocence.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Alas! I knew your rage and grief proceeded from your love to me: so I conceived it.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.p: My good son, I'll bear with many faults in thee hereafter. Bear thou with mine.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: The peace is soon concluded.

sp.speaker: O. Cart.
sp.p: Why Mr. Thorney, d'ye mean to talk out your dinner? the company attends your coming. What must it be, Mr. Frank ▪ or son Frank? I am plain Dunstable.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: Son, brother, if your daughter like to have it so.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I dare be confident, she's not altered
From what I left her at our parting last:
Are you, fair maid?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: You took too sure possession
Of an engaged heart.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Which now I challenge.

sp.speaker: O. Cart.
sp.p: Marry and much good may it do thee, son. Take her to thee. Get me a brace of boys at a burden, Frank. The nursing shall not stand thee in a pennyworth of milk. Reach her home and spare not. When's the day?

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: Tomorrow, if you please. To use ceremony
Of charge and custom, were to little purpose:
their loves are married fast enough already.

sp.speaker: O. Cart.
sp.p: A good motion. We'll e'en have an household dinner; and let the fiddlers go scrape. Let the bride and bridegroom dance at night together: no matter for the guests. Tomorrow, sue, tomorrow. Shall's to dinner now?

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: We are on all sides pleased, I hope.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Pray heaven I may deserve the blessing sent me.
Now my heart is settled.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: So is mine.

sp.speaker: O. Cart.
sp.l: Your marriage-money shall be received before your
Wedding-shoes can be pulled on. Blessing on you both.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: No man can hide his shame from heaven that views him.
In vain he flees, whose destiny pursues him.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: And why on me? why should the envious world
Throw all their scandalous malice upon me?
'Cause I am poor, deformed and ignorant,
And like a bow buckled and bent together,
By some more strong in mischiefs than myself?
Must I for that be made a common sink,
For all the filth and rubbish of men's tongues
To fall and run into? Some call me witch;
And being ignorant of myself, they go
About to teach me how to be one: urging,
That my bad tongue (By their bad usage made so)
Forespeaks their cattle, doth bewitch their corn,
Themselves, their servants, and their babes at nurse.
This they enforce upon me: and in part
Make me to credit it. And here comes one
Of my chief adversaries.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.l: Out, out upon thee, witch.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Dost call me witch?

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.p: I do, witch, I do: and worse I would, knew I a name more hateful. What makest thou upon my ground?

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Gather a few rotten sticks to warm me.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.l: Down with them when I bid thee, quickly;
I'll make thy bones rattle in thy skin else.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: You-won't, churl. Cutthroat, miser: there they be. Would they stuck cross thy throat, thy bowels, thy maw, thy midriff.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.l: Sayst thou me so? Hag, out of my ground.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: Dost strike me ▪ slave? curmudgeon now thy bones aches, thy joints cramps, and convulsions stretch and crack thy sinews.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.l: Cursing, thou hag! take that, and that.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Strike, do, and withered may that hand and arm
Whose blows have lamed me, drop from the rotten trunk.
Abuse me! beat me! call me hag and witch!
What is the name? where and by what art learned?
What spells, what charms, or invocations?
May the thing called familiar be purchased?
sp.stage: Enter young banks, and three or four more.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: A new head for the tabor, and silver tipping for the pipe. Remember that, and forget not five lesh of new bells.

sp.l: Double bells: crooked lane ye shall have 'em straight in.
Crooked lane: double bells all, if it be possible.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: Double bells? double coxcombs; trebles: buy me trebles, all trebles: for our purpose is to be in the altitudes.

sp.l: All trebles? not a mean?

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: Not one: the morris is so cast, we'll have neither mean nor base in our company, fellow Rowland.

sp.l: What? nor a counter?

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: By no means, no hunting counter; leave that to Envile chase-men: all trebles, all in the altitudes. Now for the disposing of parts in the morris, little or no labour will serve.
If you that be minded to follow your leader, know me, an ancient honour belonging to our house, for a fore-horse, team, and for gallant in a morris: my father's stable is not unfurnished.

sp.l: So much for the fore-horse: but how for a good hobby-horse?

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: For a hobby-horse? Let me see an almanac. Midsummer-moon, let me see ye. When the moon's in the full, then's wit in the wane. No more. Use your best skill. Your morris will suffer an eclipse.

sp.l: An eclipse?

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.l: A strange one.
Strange?

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: Yes, and most sudden. Remember the fore gallant, and forget the hobby-horse. The whole body of your morris will be darkened. There be of us. But 'tis no matter. Forget the hobby-horse.
Cuddy banks, have you forgotten since he paced it from Envile chase to Edmonton? Cuddy, honest Cuddy, cast thy stuff.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: Suffer may ye all. It shall be known, I can take mine ease as well as another man. Seek your hobby-horse where you can get him.

sp.l: Cuddy, honest Cuddy, we confess, and are sorry for our neglect.
The old horse shall have a new bridle.
The caparisons new painted.
The tail repaired.
The snaffle and the bosses new saffroned o'er.
Kind:
Honest:
Loving, ingenious:
Affable Cuddy.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: To show I am not flint; but affable, as you say, very well stuffed, a kind of warm dough or puff-paste, I relent, I connive, most affable Jack: let the hobby-horse provide a strong back, he shall not want a belly when I am in 'em. But uds me, mother Sawyer.

sp.l: The old witch of Edmonton. If our mirth be not crossed.

sp.p: Bless us, Cuddy, and let her curse her tother eye out. What dost now?

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: Ungirt, unblessed, says the proverb. But my girdle shall serve a riding knit: and a fig for all the witches in Christendom. What wouldst thou?

sp.l: The devil cannot abide to be crossed.
And scorns to come at any man's whistle.
Away
With the witch.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Away with the witch of Edmonton.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Still vexed? still tortured? That curmudgeon banks
Is ground of all my scandal. I am shunned
And hated like a sickness: made a scorn
To all degrees and sexes. I have heard old beldames
Talk of familiars in the shape of mice,
Rats, ferrets, weasels, and I wot not what,
that have appeared, and sucked, some say, their blood.
But by what means they came acquainted with them,
I'm now ignorant: would some power good or bad
Instruct me which way I might be revenged
Upon this churl, I'd go out of myself,
And give this fury leave to dwell within
This ruined cottage, ready to fall with age:
Abjure all goodness: be at hate with prayer;
And study curses, imprecations,
Blasphemous speeches, oaths, detested oaths,
Or any thing that's ill; so I might work
Revenge upon this miser, this black cur,
That barks, and bites, and sucks the very blood
Of me, and of my credit. 'tis all one,
To be a witch, as to be counted one.
Vengeance, shame, ruin, light upon that canker.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Ho! have I found thee cursing? now thou art mine own.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Thine? what art thou?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: He thou hast so often importuned to appear to thee, the devil.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Bless me! the devil?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Come, do not fear, I love thee much too well
To hurt or fright thee. If I seem terrible,
It is to such as hate me. I have found
Thy love unfeigned; have seen and pitied
Thy open wrongs, and come out of my love
To give thee just revenge against thy foes.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: May I believe thee?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: To confirm't, command me
Do any mischief unto man or beast,
And I'll effect it, on condition,
That uncompelled thou make a deed of gift
Of soul and body to me.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Out, alas!
My soul and body?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: And that instantly,
And seal it with thy blood: if thou deniest,
I'll tear thy body in a thousand pieces.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: I know not where to seek relief: but shall I
after such covenants sealed, see full revenge
On all that wrong me?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Ha, ha, silly woman!
The devil is no liar to such as he loves.
Didst ever know or hear the devil a liar
To such as he affects?

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: When I am thine, at least so much of me,
As I can call mine own.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Equivocations?
Art mine or no? speak, or I'll tear.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: All thine.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Seal't with thy blood.
See, now I dare call thee mine;
For proof, command me, instantly I'll run,
To any mischief, goodness can I none.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: And I desire as little. There's an old churl, one banks —

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: That wronged thee: he lamed thee, called thee witch.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: The same: first upon him I'd be revenged.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Thou shalt: do but name how.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Go, touch his life.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Hast thou not vowed? Go, kill the slave.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: I wonot.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: I'll cancel then my gift.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Dost laugh?
Why wilt not kill him?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Fool, because I cannot.
Though we have power, know, it is circumscribed,
And tied in limits: though he be cursed to thee,
Yet of himself he is loving to the world,
And charitable to the poor. Now men
That, as he, love goodness, though in smallest measure,
Live without compass of our reach. His cattle
And corn, I'll kill and mildew: but his life
(Until I take him, as I late found thee,
Cursing and swearing) I have no power to touch.

sp.speaker: Saw.
sp.l: Work on his corn and cattle then.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: I shall.
The witch of Edmonton shall see his fall.
If she at least put credit in my power,
And in mine only; make orisons to me,
And none but me.

sp.speaker: Saw.
sp.l: Say how, and in what manner?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: I'll tell thee, when thou wishest ill;
corn, man or beast, would spoil or kill,
Turn thy back against the sun,
And mumble this short orison:
If thou to death or shame pursue 'em,
Sanctibicetur nomen tuum.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: If thou to death or shame pursue 'em,
Sanctibecetur nomen tuum.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Perfect. Farewell. Our first-made promises
We'll put in execution against banks.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Contaminetur nomen tuum. I'm an expert scholar;
Speak Latin, or I know not well what language,
As well as the best of 'em. But who comes here?
The son of my worst foe. To death pursue 'em,
Et sanctabecetur nomen tuum.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.l: What is that she mumbles? the devils pater noster?
Would it were else. Mother Sawyer, good morrow.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: Ill morrow to thee, and all the world, that flout a poor old woman. To death pursue 'em, and sanctabacetur nomen tuum.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.l: Nay, good gammer Sawyer, whate'er it pleases my
Father to call you, I know you are

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: A witch.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.l: A witch? would you were else i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Your father knows I am by this.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.l: I would he did.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: And so in time may you.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: I would I might else. But witch or no witch, you are a motherly woman: and though my father be a kind of God bless us, as they say, I have an earnest suit to you; and if you'll be so kind to ka me one good turn, I'll be so courteous as to kob you another.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: What's that? to spurn, beat me, and call me witch, as your kind father doth?

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: My father? I am ashamed to own him. If he has hurt the head of thy credit, there's money to buy thee a plaster: and a small courtesy I would require at thy hands.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: You seem a good young man, and I must dissemble, the better to accomplish my revenge. But for this silver, what wouldst have me do? bewitch thee?

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p:
No, by no means; I am bewitched already. I would
have thee so good as to unwitch me, or witch another with me for company.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: I understand thee not. Be plain, my son.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.l: As a pikestaff, mother: you know Kate Carter.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: The wealthy yeoman's daughter. What of her?

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.l: That same party has bewitched me.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Bewitched thee?

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: Bewitched me, hisce auribus. I saw a little devil fly out of her eye like a burbolt, which sticks at this hour up to the feathers in my heart. Now my request is, to send one of thy what d'ye call ', either to pluck that out, or stick another as fast in hers. Do, and here's my hand, I am thine for three lives.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: We shall have sport. Thou art in love with her.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: Up to the very hilts, mother.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: And thou'dst have me make her love thee too.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: I think she'll prove a witch in earnest. Yes, I could find in my heart to strike her three quarters deep in love with me too.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: But dost thou think that I can do't, and I alone?

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: Truly, mother witch, I do verily believe so: and when I see it done, I shall be half persuaded so too.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: It's enough. What art can do, be sure of: turn to the West, and whatsoe'er thou hearest or seest, stand silent, and be not afraid.
sp.stage: Enter the dog; he fawns and leaps upon her.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: Afraid, mother witch? turn my face to the West? I said I should always have a back-friend of her; and now it's out. And her little devil should be hungry, come sneaking behind me, like a cowardly catchpole, and clap his talents on my haunches. 'tis woundy cold sure. I shudder and shake like an aspenleaf every joint of me.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: To scandal and disgrace pursue 'em,
Et sanctabicetur nomen tuum.
How now, my son, how is't?

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: Scarce in a clean life, mother witch. But did your goblin and you spout Latin together?

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: A kind of charm I work by. Didst thou hear me?

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p:
I heard I know not the devil what mumble in a scurvy
base tone, like a drum that had taken cold in the head the last muster. Very comfortable words: what were they? and who taught them you?

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: A great learned man.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: Learned man? learned devil it was as soon? But what? what comfortable news about the party?

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: Who? Kate Carter? I'll tell thee, thou knowest the style at the west-end of thy father's pease-field, be there to morrow-night after sunset; and the first live thing thou seest, be sure to follow, and that shall bring thee to thy love.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: In the pease-field? Has she a mind to codlings already? The first living thing I meet, you say, shall bring me to her.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: To a sight of her, I mean. She will seem wantonly coy, and flee thee: but follow her close, and boldly: do but embrace her in thy arms once, and she is thine own.

sp.speaker: Y. Bank.
sp.p: At the style, at the west-end of my father's peaseland, the first live thing I see, follow and embrace her, and she shall be thine. Nay, and I come to embracing once, she shall be mine; I'll go near to make at eaglet else.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: A ball well bandied: now the set is half won:
The father's wrong I'll wreak upon the son.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: How now gentlemen, cloudy? I know Mr. Warbeck, you are in a fog about my daughter's marriage.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: And can you blame me, sir?

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: Nor you me justly. Wedding and hanging are tied up both in a proverb; and destiny is the juggler that unties the knot. My hope is, you are reserved to a richer fortune than my poor daughter.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: However, your promise.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Is a kind of debt, I confess it.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: Which honest men should pay.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: Yet some gentlemen break in that point, now and then, by your leave, sir.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.p: I confess thou hast had a little wrong in the wench: but patience is the only salve to cure it. Since Thorney has won the wench, he has most reason to wear her.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: Love in this kind admits no reason to wear her.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Then loves a fool, and what wise man will take exception?

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.p: Come, frolic Ned, were every man master of his own fortune, fate might pick straws; and destiny go a woolgathering.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.p: You hold yours in a string though. 'tis well: but if there be any equity, look thou to meet the like usage ere long.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.p: In my love to her sister Katherine? Indeed, they are a pair of arrows drawn out of one quiver, and should fly at an even length, if she do run after her sister.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.p: Look for the same mercy at my hands, as I have received at thine.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.p: She'll keep a surer compass. I have too strong a confidence to mistrust her.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.p: And that confidence is a wind, that has blown many a married man ashore at cuckold's haven, I can tell you: I wish yours more prosperous though.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Whatever you wish, I'll master my promise to him.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: Yes, as you did to me.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: No more of that, if you love me. But for the more assurance, the next offered occasion shall consummate the marriage: and that once sealed,

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.p: Leave the manage of the rest to my care. But see, the bridegroom and bride comes; the new pair of sheffeild-knives fitted both to one sheath.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.p: The sheath might have been better fitted, if somebody had their due. But —

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: No harsh language, if thou lovest me. Frank Thorney has done —

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.p: No more than I, or thou, or any man, things so standing, would have attempted.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Good morrow Mr. bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.p: Come, give thee joy. Mayst thou live long and happy in thy fair choice.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.p: I thank ye gentlemen. Kind Mr. Warbeck, I find you loving.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: Thorney, that creature, (Much good do thee with her)
Virtue and beauty hold fair mixture in her.
She's rich no doubt in both. Yet were she fairer,
Thou art right worthy of her. Love her, Thorney,
'Tis nobleness in thee, in her but duty.
The match is fair and equal: the success
I leave to censure. Farewell, Mrs. Bride:
Till now elected, thy old scorn deride.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Good, Mr. Thorney.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: Nay, you shall not part till you see the barrels run a-tilt, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Why change you your face, sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Who? I? For nothing.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Dear, say not so: a spirit of your constancy cannot endure his change for nothing. I have observed strange variations in you.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: In me?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: In you, sir. Awake: you seem to dream, and in your sleep you utter sudden and distracted accents, like one at enmity with peace. Dear loving husband, if I may dare to challenge any interest in you, give me the reason fully: you may trust my breast as safely as your own.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: With what? you half amaze me, prithee.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Come, you shall not; indeed, you shall not shut me from partaking the least dislike that grieves you. I am all yours.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: And I all thine.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: You are not, if you keep the least grief from me: but I find the cause; it grew from me.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: From you?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: From some distaste in me or my behaviour: you are not kind in the concealment. Alas, sir, I am young, silly, and plain; more strange to those contents a wife should offer. Say but in what I fail, I'll study satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Come, in nothing.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: I know I do. Knew I as well in what, you should not long be sullen. Prithee love, if I have been immodest or too bold, speak't in a frown: if peevishly too nice, show't in a smile. Thy liking is the glass by which I'll habit my behaviour.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Wherefore dost weep now?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: You, sweet, have the power to make me passionate as an april-day: now smile, then weep; now pale, then crimson red. You are the powerful moon of my blood's sea, to make it ebb or flow into my face, as your looks change.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Change thy conceit, I prithee:
Thou art all perfection: Diana herself
Swells in thy thoughts, and moderates thy beauty.
Within thy left eye amorous Cupid fits
Feathering love-shafts, whose golden heads he dipped
— in thy chaste breast. In the other lies
Blushing Adonis scarfed in modesties.
And still as wanton Cupid blows love-fires,
Adonis quenches our unchaste desires.
And from these two I briefly do imply
A perfect emblem of thy modesty.
Then, prithee dear, maintain no more dispute,
For where thou speakst, it's fit all tongues be mute.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Come, come, those golden strings of flattery
Shall not tie up my speech, sir; I must know
The ground of your disturbance.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Then look here;
For here, here is the fen in which this Hydra
Of discontent grows rank.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Heaven shield it: where?

sp.speaker: Y. Tho.
sp.l: In mine own bosom: here the cause has root;
The poisoned leeches twist about my heart,
And will, I hope, confound me.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: You speak riddles.

sp.speaker: Y. Tho.
sp.l: Take't plainly then: 'twas told me by a woman
Known and approved in palmistry,
I should have two wives.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Two wives? Sir, I take it exceeding likely. But let not conceit hurt you: you are afraid to bury me?

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: No, no, my Winifrid.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: How say you? Winifrid? you forget me.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: No, I forget myself, Susan.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: In what?

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Talking of wives, I pretend Winifrid,
A maid that at my mother's waited on me
Before thyself.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: I hope, sir, she may live to take my place. But why should all this move you?

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.p: The poor girl, she hast before thee, and that's the fiend torments me.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Yet why should this raise mutiny within you? such presages prove often false: or say it should be true?

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: That I should have another wife?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Yes, many; if they be good, the better.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Never any equal to thee in goodness.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Sir, I could wish I were much better for you;
Yet if I knew your fate
Ordained you for another, I could wish
(So well I love you, and your hopeful pleasure)
Me in my grave, and my poor virtues added
To my successor.

sp.speaker: Y. thorn
sp.p: Prithee, prithee, talk not of death or graves; thou art so rare a goodness, as death would rather put itself to death, then murder thee. But we, as all things else, are mutable and hanging.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Yet you still move in your first sphere of discontent. Sweet, chase those clouds of sorrow, and shine clearly on me.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: At my return I will.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Return? ah me! will you then leave me?

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.p: For a time I must: but how? as birds their young, or loving bees their hives, to fetch home richer dainties.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Leave me? Now has my fear met its effect. You shall not, cost it my life, you shall not.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Why? your reason?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Like to the lapwing have you all this while with your false love deluded me? pretending counterfeit senses for your discontent, and now at last it is by chance stole from you.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: What? what by chance?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Your pre-appointed meeting of single combat with young Warbeck.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Even so: dissemble not; 'tis too apparent. Then in his look I read it: deny it not; I see't apparent: cost it my undoing, and unto that my life, I will not leave you.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Not until when?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Till he and you be friends.
Was this your cunning? and then flam me off
With an old witch, two wives, and Winifrid?
You're not so kind indeed as I imagined.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: And you more fond by far then I expected.
It is a virtue that attends thy kind.
But of our business within: and by this kiss,
I'll anger thee no more; troth chuck I will not.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: You shall have no just cause,

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Dear sue, I shall not.

sp.p: Nay, Cuddy, prithee do not leave us now: if we part all this night, we shall not meet before day.

sp.l: I prithee, banks, let's keep together now.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: If you were wise, a word would serve: but as you are, I must be forced to tell you again, I have a little private business, an hours work; it may prove but an half hours, as luck may serve; and than I take horse and along with you. Have we e'er a witch in the morris?
No, no; no woman's part, but maid-marian, and the hobby-horse.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I'll have a witch; I love a witch.

sp.p: Faith, witches themselves are so common nowadays , that the counterfeit will not be regarded. They say we have three or four in Edmonton, besides mother Sawyer.

sp.l: I would she would dance her part with us.

sp.p: So would not I; for if she comes, the devil and all comes along with her.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Well, I'll have a witch: I have loved a witch ever since I played at cherry-pit. Leave me, and get my horse dressed: give him oats; but water him not till I come. Whither do we foot it first?

sp.l: To sir Arthur Clarington's first, then whither thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Well, I'm content: but we must up to Carter's, the rich yeoman. I must be seen on hobby-horse there.
O, I smell him now: I'll lay my ears banks is in love, and that's the reason he would walk melancholy by himself.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ha! who was that said I was in love?
Not I.
Not I.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Go to: no more of that. When I understand what you speak, I know what you say: believe that.
Well, 'twas I, I'll not deny it: I meant no hurt in't. I have seen you walk up to Carter's of Chessum. Banks, were not you there last Shrovetide?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Yes, I was ten days together there the last Shrovetide.

sp.p: How could that be, when there are but seven days in the week?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Prithee peace, I reckon stila nova, as a traveller: thou understandest as a freshwater farmer, that never sawest a week beyond sea. Ask any soldier that ever received his pay but in the low countries, and he'll tell thee there are eight days in the week there, hard by. How dost thou think they rise in high Germany, Italy, and those remoter places?

sp.l: Ay, but simply there are but seven days in the week yet.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: No, simply as thou understandest. Prithee, look but in the lover's almanac, when he has been but three days absent; o, says he, I have not seen my love these seven years: there's a long cut. When he comes to her again, and embraces her, oh, says he, now methinks I am in heaven; and that's a pretty step: he that can get up to heaven in ten days, need not repent his journey. You may ride a hundred days in a caroche, and be further off than when you set forth. But I pray you, good morrice-mates, now leave me. I will be with you by midnight.
Well, since he will be alone, we'll back again, and trouble him no more.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: But remember, banks.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: The hobby-horse shall be remembered. But hark you: get Poldavis, the barber's boy for the witch; because he can show his art better than another.

Well, now to my walk. I am near the place where I should meet
I know not what: say I meet a thief, I must follow him, if to the gallows: say I meet a horse, or hare, or hound, still I must follow; some slow-paced beast, I hope: yet love is full of lightness in the heaviest lovers. Ha! my guide is come. A water-dog. I am thy first man, sculler: I go with thee: ply no other but myself: away with the boat: land me but at Katherine's dock, my sweet Katherine's dock, and I'll be a fare to thee. That way? nay, which way thou wilt, thou knowest the way better than I. Fine gentle cur it is, and well brought up, I warrant him. We go a ducking, spaniel; thou shalt fetch me the ducks, pretty kind rascal.
sp.stage: Enter spirit in shape of Katherine, vizarded, and takes it off.

sp.speaker: Spirit
sp.l: Thus throw I off mine own essential horror,
And take the shape of a sweet lovely maid
Whom this fool dotes on. We can meet his folly,
But from his virtues must be runaways.
We'll sport with him: but when we reckoning call,
We know where to receive: th' witch pays for all.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I? is that the watchword? She's come. Well, if ever we be married, it shall be at Barking-church, in memory of thee. Now come behind, kind cur.
sp.l: And have I met thee, sweet Kate?
I will teach thee to walk so late.
sp.p: O see, we meet in metre. What? dost thou trip from me? O that I were upon my hobby-horse, I would mount after thee so nimble. Stay, nymph, stay, nymph, singed Apollo: tarry and kiss me; sweet nymph stay: tarry and kiss me, sweet. We will to Chessum-street, and then to the house stands in the highway. Nay, by your leave, I must embrace you. O help, help, I am drowned, I am drowned.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: This was an ill night to go a-wooing in; I find it now in Pond's almanac: thinking to land at Katherine's dock, I was almost at Gravesend. I'll never go to a wench in the dog-days again; yet 'tis cool enough. Had you never a paw in this dogtrick? A mangy take that black hide of yours: I'll throw you in at limehouse in some tanner's pit or other.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: How now? who's that laughs at me? Hist to him. [dog barks.]peace, peace; thou didst but thy kind neither. 'twas my own fault.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Take heed how thou trustest the devil another time.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: How now? who's that speaks? I hope you have not your reading tongue about you.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Yes, I can speak.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: The devil you can. You have read Esop's fables then: I have played one of your parts then; the dog that catched at the shadow in the water. Pray you, let me catechise you a little: what might one call your name, dog?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: My dame calls me Tom.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: 'Tis well; and she may call me ass: so there's an whole one betwixt us, tom-ass. She said, I should follow you, indeed. Well, Tom, give me thy fist; we are friends: you shall be mine ingle: I love you; but I pray you let's have no more of these ducking devices.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Not, if you love me. Dog's love where they are beloved. Cherish me, and I'll do any thing for thee.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Well, you shall have jowls and livers: I have butchers to my friends that shall bestow 'em: and I will keep crusts and bones for you, if you'll be a kind dog, Tom.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Any thing: I'll help thee to thy love.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Wilt thou? That promise shall cost me a brown loaf, though I steal it out of my father's cupboard. You'll eat stolen goods, Tom, will you not?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: O best of all. The sweetest bits, those.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: You shall not starve, ningle Tom; believe that, if you love fish, I'll help you to maids and soles. I'm acquainted with a fishmonger.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Maids and soles? O, sweet bits! Banqueting stuff, those.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: One thing I would request you, ningle, as you have played the knavish cur with me a little, that you would mingle amongst our morris-dancers in the morning. You can dance?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Yes, yes, any thing: I'll be there, but unseen to any but thyself. Get thee gone before: fear not my presence. I have work tonight . I serve more masters, more dames than one.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: He can serve Mammon and the devil too.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: It shall concern thee, and thy love's purchase:
There's a gallant rival loves the maid;
And likely is to have her. Mark what a mischief
Before the morris ends, shall light on him.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: On sweet ningle, thy news once again. Friend's must part for a time: farewell, with this remembrance; shalt have bread too when we meet again. If ever there were an honest devil, 'twill be the devil of Edmonton, I see. Farewell Tom. I prithee dog me as soon as thou canst.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: I'll not miss thee, and be merry with thee.
Those that are joys denied, must take delight
In sins and mischiefs, 'tis the devil's right.
sp.stage: Enter young Thorney, Winnifride as a boy.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Prithee no more: those tears give nourishment
To weeds and briers in me, which shortly will
O'ergrow and top my head: my shame will sit
And cover all that can be seen of me.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I have not shown this check in company,
Pardon me now: thus singled with yourself,
It calls a thousand sorrows round about.
Some going before, and some on either side;
But infinite behind: all chained together.
Your second adulterous marriage leads;
That's the sad eclipse, the effects must follow.
As, plagues of shame, spite, scorn, and obloquy.

sp.speaker: Y. Tho.
sp.l: Why? hast thou not left one hours patience
To add to all the rest? One hour bears us
Beyond the reach of all these enemies.
Are we not now set forward in the flight,
Provided with the dowry of my sin,
To keep us in some other nation?
While we together are, we are at home
In any place.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: 'Tis fowl ill gotten coin,
Far worse than usury or extortion.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Let my father then make the restitution,
Who forced me take the bribe: it is his gift
And patrimony to me; so I receive it.
He would not bless, not look a father on me,
until I satisfied his angry will.
When I was sold, I sold myself again
(Some knaves have done't in lands, and I in body)
For money, and I have the hire. But, sweet, no more,
'Tis hazard of discovery, our discourse;
And then prevention takes off all our hopes.
For only but to take her leave of me,
My wife is coming.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Who coming? your wife?

sp.speaker: Y. Tho.
sp.l: No, no, thou art here: the woman; I knew
Not how to call her now: but after this day
She shall be quite forgotten, and have no name
In my remembrance. See, see, she's come.
To lead the horses to the hill's top, there I'll meet thee.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Nay, with your favour, let him stay a little.
I would part with him too, because he is
Your sole companion; and I'll begin with him,
Reserving you the last.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Ay, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: You may hear, if it please you, sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: No, 'tis not fit.
Some rudiments, I conceive, they must be,
To overlook my slippery footings. And so.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: No, indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Tush, I know it must be so, and 'tis necessary.
On, but be brief.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: What charge soe'er you lay upon me, mistress,
I shall support it faithfully (Being honest)
To my best strength.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Believe 't shall be no other. I know you were
Commended to my husband by a noble knight.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: O gods! O, mine eyes!

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: How now? what ailst thou, lad?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Something hit mine eye, it makes it water still,
Even as you said, commended to my husband.
Some door I think it was. I was, forsooth,
Commended to him by sir Arthur Clarington.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Whose servant once my Thorney was himself.
That title methinks should make you almost fellows,
Or at the least much more than a servant;
And I am sure he will respect you so.
Your love to him then needs no spur for me,
And what for my sake you will ever do;
'Tis fit it should be bought with something more
Than fair entreaties. Look here's a jewel for thee,
A pretty wanton label for thine ear;
And I would have it hang there, still to whisper
These words to thee, thou hast my jewel with thee.
It is but earnest of a larger bounty,
When thou returnest, with praises of thy service,
Which I am confident thou wilt deserve.
Why, thou art many now, besides thyself:
Thou mayst be servant, friend, and wife to him.
A good wife is then all. A friend can play
The wife and servants part, and shift enough.
No less the servant can the friend and wife.
'Tis all but sweet society, good counsel,
Interchanged loves; yes, and counsel-keeping.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Not done yet?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Even now, sir.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Mistress, believe my vow, your severe eye
Were it present to command; your bounteous hand,
Were it then by to buy or bribe my service,
Shall not make me more dear or near unto him,
Than I shall voluntary. I'll be all your charge,
Servant, friend, wife to him.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Wilt thou?
Now blessings go with thee for't: courtesies
Shall meet thee coming home.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Pray you say plainly, mistress,
Are you jealous of him? if you be,
I'll look to him that way too.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Sayst thou so?
I would thou hadst a woman's bosom now.
We have weak thoughts within us. Alas,
There's nothing so strong in us as suspicion:
But I dare not, nay, I will not think
So hardly of my Thorney.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Believe it, mistress,
I'll be no pander to him; and if I find
Any loose lubric scapes in him, I'll watch him,
And at my return, protest I'll show you all.
He shall hardly offend without my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Thine own diligence is that I press,
And not the curious eye over his faults.
Farewell: if I should never see thee more,
Take it for ever.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Prithee take that along with thee,
And haste thee to the hill's top; I'll be there instantly.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: No haste I prithee, slowly as thou canst.
Pray let him obey me now: 'tis happily his last
Service to me. My power is e'en a going out of sight.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Why would you delay? we have no other
Business now but to part.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: And will not that, sweet heart, ask a long time?
Methinks it is the hardest piece of work
That e'er I took in hand.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Fie, fie, why look,
I'll make it plain and easy to you: farewell.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Ah, alas! I am not half perfect in it yet.
I must have it read over an hundred times.
Pray you take some pains, I confess my dulness.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: What a thorn this rose grows on? parting were sweet.
But what a trouble 'twill be to obtain it?
Come, again and again, farewell. Yet wilt return?
All questions of my journey, my stay, employment,
And revisitation, fully I have answered all.
There's nothing now behind, but nothing.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: And that nothing is more hard than any thing,
Than all the every things. This request.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: That I may bring you through one pasture more
Up to you knot of trees: amongst those shadows
I'll vanish from you, they shall teach me how.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Why, 'tis granted: come, walk then.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Nay, not too fast.
They say slow things have best perfection:
The gentle shower wets to fertility.
The churlish storm may mischief with his bounty.
The baser beasts take strength, even from the womb:
But the lord lion's whelp is feeble long.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Now for an early mischief and a sudden:
The mind's about it now. One touch from me
Soon sets the body forward.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Your request is out: yet will you leave me?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: What? so churlishly? you'll make me stay for ever,
Rather than part with such a sound from you.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Why you almost anger me. Pray you be gone.
You have no company, and 'tis very early;
Some hurt may betide you homewards.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Tush, I fear none.
To leave you, is the greatest hurt I can suffer:
Besides, I expect your father and mine own,
To meet me back, or overtake me with you.
They began to stir when I came after you:
I know they'll not be long.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: So, I shall have more trouble.
Thank you for that. Then I'll ease all at once.
'Tis done now: what I ne'er thought on. You shall not go back.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Why? shall I go along with thee? sweet music!

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: No, to a better place.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Any place, I:
I'm there at home, where thou pleasest to have me.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: At home? I'll leave you in your last lodging.
I must kill you.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: O fine! you'd fright me from you.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.p: You see I had no purpose: I'm unarmed. 'tis this minute's decree, and it must be. Look, this will serve your turn.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: I'll not turn from it, if you be erst, sir. Yet you may tell me wherefore you'll kill me.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Because you are a whore.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: There's one deep wound already: a whore?
'Twas ever further from me then the thought
Of this black hour: a whore?

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Yes, I'll prove it,
And you shall confess it. You are my whore,
No wife of mine. The word admits no second.
I was before wedded to another, have her still.
I do not lay the sin unto your charge,
'Tis all mine own. Your marriage was my theft.
For I espoused your dowry, and I have it:
I did not purpose to have added murder;
The devil did not prompt me: till this minute
You might have safe returned; now you cannot:
You have dogged your own death.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: And I deserve it.
I'm glad my fate was so intelligent.
'Twas some good spirits motion. Die? o, 'twas time!
How many years might I have slept in sin?
Sin of my most hatred too, adultery?

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Nay, sure 'twas likely that the most was passed;
For I meant never to return to you
After this parting.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Why then I thank you more,
You have done lovingly, leaving yourself,
That you would thus bestow me on another.
Thou art my husband, death, and I embrace thee
With all the love I have. Forget the stain
Of my unwitting sin: and then I come
A crystal virgin to thee. My soul's purity
Shall with bold wings ascend the doors of mercy;
For innocence is ever her companion.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Not yet mortal? I would not linger you,
Or leave you a tongue to blab.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Now heaven reward you ne'er the worse for me.
I did not think that death had been so sweet;
Nor I so apt to love him. I could ne'er die better,
Had I stayed forty years for preparation:
For I'm in charity with all the world.
Let me for once be thine example, heaven;
Do to this man as I him free forgive.
And may he better die, and better live.

sp.speaker: Y. Tho.
sp.l: 'Tis done; and I am in: once passed our height,
We scorn the deep'st abyss. This follows now,
To heal her wounds by dressing of the weapon:
Arms, thighs, hands, any place; we must not fail,
Light scratches giving such deep ones. The best I can
to bind myself to this tree. Now's the storm,
Which if blown o'er, many fair days may follow.
So, so, I'm fast; I did not think I could
Have done so well behind me. How prosperous
And effectual mischief sometimes is? Help, help;
Murder, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Ha! whom tolls the bell for?

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: O, o!

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: Ah me! the cause appears too soon: my child, my son.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Susan, girl, child. Not speak to thy father? Ha!

sp.speaker: Y. Tho.
sp.l: O lend me some assistance to o'ertake this hapless woman.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.p: Let's o'ertake the murderers. Speak whilst thou canst; anon may be too late. I fear thou hast deaths mark upon thee too.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: I know them both; yet such an oath is passed,
As pulls damnation up if it be broke;
I dare not name 'em: think what forced men do.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.p: Keep oath with murderers? that were a conscience to hold the devil in.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: Nay, sir, I can describe 'em;
Shall show them as familiar as their names.
The taller of the two at this time wears
His satin-doublet white, but crimson lined;
Hose of black satin, cloak of scarlet.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: Warbeck, Warbeck, Warbeck: do you list to this, sir?

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Yes, yes, I listen you: here's nothing to be heard.

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.p: Th' others cloak branched velvet black, velvet lined his suit.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: I have 'em already: Somerton, Somerton.
Binal revenge, all this. Come, sir, the first work
Is to pursue the murderers, when we have removed
These mangled bodies hence.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Sir, take that carcase there, and give me this.
I'll not own her now; she's none of mine.
Bob me off with a dumb show? No, I'll have life.
This is my son too, and while there's life in him,
'Tis half mine; take you half that silence for 't.
When I speak, I look to be spoken to: forgetful slut?

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: Alas! what grief may do now?
Look, sir, I'll take this load of sorrow with me.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Ay, do, and I'll hear this. How do you, sir?

sp.speaker: Y. Thor.
sp.l: O, very ill, sir.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Yes, I think so; but 'tis well you can speak yet.
There's no music but in sound, sound it must be.
I have not wept these twenty years before,
And that I guess was ere that girl was born:
Yet now methinks, if I but knew the way,
My heart's so full, I could weep night and day.
sp.stage: Enter sir Arthur Clarington, Warbeck, Somerton.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Come, gentlemen, we must all help to grace
The nimble-footed youth of Edmonton, that are so kind
To call us up today with an high morris.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: I could wish it for the best, it were the worst now.
Absurdity's in my opinion ever the best dancer in a morris.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: I could rather sleep than see 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Not well, sir?

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Faith not ever thus leaden; yet I know no cause for 't.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.p: Now am I beyond mine own condition highly disposed to mirth.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Well, you may have yet a morris to help both;
To strike you in a dump, and make him merry.
sp.stage: Enter fiddler and Morrice; all but banks.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Come, will you set yourselves in morris-array? the fore-bell, second bell, tenor and great bell; maid-marian for the same bell. But where's the weathercock now? the hobby-horse?

sp.l: Is not banks come yet? What a spite 'tis?

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: When set you forward, gentlemen?

sp.p: We stay but for the hobby-horse, sir: all our footmen are ready.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: 'Tis marvel your horse should be behind your foot.
Yes, sir: he goes further about: we can come in at the
Wicket, but the broad gate must be opened for him.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: O, we stayed for you, sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Only my horse wanted a shoe, sir: but we shall make you amends ere we part.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: I? well said, make 'em drink ere they begin.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
A bowl, I prithee, and a little for my horse,[with beer.
He'll mount the better. Nay, give me, I must drink to him, he'll not pledge else. Here hobby. [holds him the bowl.]I pray you: no? not drink? You see, gentlemen, we can but bring our horse to the water; he may choose whether he'll drink or no.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: A good moral made plain by history.
Strike up, father Sawgut, strike up.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: E'en when you will, children. Now in the name of the best foot forward. How now? not a word in thy guts? I think, children, my instrument has caught cold on the sudden.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: My ningle's knavery: black Tom's doing.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Why what mean you, father Sawgut?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Why what would you have him do? You hear his fiddle is speechless.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: I'll lay mine ear to my instrument, that my poor fiddle is bewitched. I played the flowers in may, e'en now, as sweet as a violet; now 'twill not go against the hair: you see I can make no more music than a beetle of a cow-turd.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Let me see, father Sawgut, say, once you had a brave hobby-horse, that you were beholding to. I'll play and dance too. Ningle, away with it.
sp.stage: [dog plays the morris; which ended, enter a constable and officers.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: I marry, sir!

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Away with jollity, 'tis too sad an hour.
Sir Arthur Clarington, your own assistance,
In the King's name, I charge, for apprehension
Of these two murderers, Warbeck and Somerton.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Ha! flat murderers?

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, this has awakened my melancholy.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: And struck my mirth down flat. Murderers?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: The accusation is flat against you, gentlemen.
Sir, you may be satisfied with this. I hope
You'll quietly obey my power;
'Twill make your cause the fairer.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: Oh! with all our hearts, sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
There's my rival taken up for hangman's meat. Tom told me he was about a piece of villainy. Mates and morricemen, you see here's no longer piping, no longer dancing. This news of murder has slain the morris. You that go the footway,
fare ye well: I am for a Gallop. Come, ningle.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: [strikes his fiddle.]I? Nay and my fiddle be come to himself again, I care not. I think the devil has been abroad amongst us today. I'll keep thee out of thy fit now if I can.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: These things are full of horror, full of pity.
But if this time be constant to the proof,
The guilt of both these gentlemen I dare take
Upon mine own danger; yet howsoever, sir,
Your power must be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: O most willingly, sir.
'Tis a most sweet affliction. I could not meet
A joy in the best shape with better will.
Come, fear not, sir; nor judge, nor evidence,
Can bind him o'er, who's freed by conscience.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Mine stands so upright to the middle zone,
It takes no shadow to't, it goes alone.

sp.stage: Enter old banks, and two or three countrymen.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.p: My horse this morning runs most piteous of the glanders, whose nose yesternight was as clean as any man's here now coming from the barbers; and this I'll take my death upon 'tis long of this jadish witch, mother Sawyer.

I took my wife and a servingman in our town of Edmonton, thrashing in my barn together, such corn as country-wenches carry to market; and examining my polecat why she did so, she swore in her conscience she was bewitched: and what witch have we about us, but mother Sawyer?
Rid the town of her, else all our wives will do nothing else but dance all out other country maypoles.
Our cattle fall, our wives fall, our daughters fall, and maidservants fall; and we ourselves shall not be able to stand, if this beast be suffered to graze amongst us.
sp.stage: Enter W. Hamlac, with thatch and a link.

sp.speaker: Haml.
sp.l: Burn the witch, the witch, the witch, the witch.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: What hast got there?

sp.speaker: Haml.
sp.p: A handful of thatch plucked off a hovel of hers: and they say, when 'tis burning, if she be a witch, she'll come running in.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.p: Fire it, fire it: I'll stand between thee and home for any danger.
sp.stage: As that burns, enter the witch.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: Diseases, plagues; the curse of an old woman follow and fall upon you.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Are you come, you old trot?

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.l: You hot whore, must we fetch you with fire in your tail?
This thatch is as good as a jury to prove she is a witch.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Out witch; beat her, kick her, set fire on her.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Shall I be murdered by a bed of serpents? help, help!
sp.stage: Enter sir Arthur Clarington, and a justice.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Hang her, beat her, kill her.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: How now? Forbear this violence.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: A crew of villains, a knot of bloody hangmen set to torment me I know not why.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Alas, neighbour banks, are you a ringleader in mischief:
Fie, to abuse an aged woman!

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.p: Woman? A she-hell-cat, a witch: to prove her one, we no sooner set fire on the thatch of her house, but in she came running, as if the devil had sent her in a barrel of gunpowder; which trick as surely proves her a witch, as the pox in a snuffling nose, is a sign a man is a whoremaster.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Come, come; firing her thatch? ridiculous: take heed sirs what you do: unless your proofs come better armed, instead of turning her into a witch, you'll prove yourselves stark fools.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Fool's?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Arrant fools.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. justice what do you call 'em, hear me but in one thing: this grumbling devil owes me I know no good will ever since I fell out with her.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: And brakedst my back with beating me.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.l: I'll break it worse.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: You must not threaten her: 'tis against law. Go on.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
