sp.p: So, sir, ever since, having a dun-cow tied up in my backside, let me go thither, or but cast mine eye at her, and if I should be hanged, I cannot choose, though it be ten times in an hour, but run to the cow, and taking up her tail, kiss (Saving your worship's reverence) my gow behind; that the whole town of Edmonton has been ready to bepiss themselves with laughing me to scorn.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: And this is long of her?

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.p: Who the devil else? for is any man such an ass, to be such a baby, if he were not bewitched?

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.p: Nay, if she be a witch, and the harms she does end in such sports, she may scape burning.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Go, go; pray vex her not: she is a subject, and you must not be judges of the law to strike her as you please.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: No, no, we'll find cudgel enough to strike her.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.l: Ay, no lips to kiss but my cow's —?

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Rots and foul maladies eat up thee and thine.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Here's none now, mother Sawyer, but this gentleman, myself and you; let us to some mild questions, have you mild answers? Tell us honestly, and with a free confession, (We'll do our best to wean you from it) are you a witch, or no?

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: I am none.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Be not so furious.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: I am none. None but base curs so bark at me. I am none. Or would I were: if every poor old woman be trod on thus by staves, reviled, kicked, beaten, as I am daily, she to be revenged had need turn witch.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: And you to be revenged have sold your soul to th'devil.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Keep thine own from him.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: You are too saucy, and too bitter.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: Saucy? by what commission can he send my soul on the devil's errand, more than I can his? is he a landlord of my soul, to thrust it when he list out of door?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Know whom you speak to.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: A man: perhaps, no man. Men in gay clothes, whose backs are laden with titles and honours, are within far more crooked than I am; and if I be a witch, more witchlike.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.p: you're a base hellhound. And now, sir, let me tell you, far and near she's bruited for a woman that maintains a spirit that sucks her.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: I defy thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Go, go, I can, if need be, bring an hundred voices e'en here in Edmonton, that shall loud proclaim thee for a secret and pernicious witch.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Do you laugh? why laugh you?

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: At my name: the brave name this knight gives me, witch.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Is the name of witch so pleasing to thine ear?

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Pray, sir, give way, and let her tongue gallop on.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: A witch? who is not?
Hold not that universal name in scorn then.
What are your painted things in princes' courts?
Upon whose eyelids lust sits blowing fires
To burn men's souls in sensual hot desires:
Upon whose naked paps, a lecher's thought
Acts sin in fouler shapes then can be wrought.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: But those work not as you do.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: No, but far worse:
These, by enchantments, can whole lordships change
To trunks of rich attire: turn ploughs and teams
To Flanders mares and coaches; and huge trains
Of servitors, to a French butterfly.
Have you not city-witches who can turn
Their husband's wares, whole standing shops of wares,
To sumptuous tables, gardens of stolen sin?
In one year wasting, what scarce twenty win.
Are not these witches?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Yes, yes, but the law
Casts not an eye on these.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Why then on me,
Or any lean old beldame? Reverence once
Had wont to wait on age. Now an old woman
Ill favoured grown with years, if she be poor,
Must be called bawd or witch. Such so abused
Are the course witches: tother are the fine,
Spun for the devil's own wearing.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: And so is thine.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: She on whose tongue a whirlwind sits to blow
A man out of himself, from his soft pillow,
To lean his head on rocks and fighting waves,
Is not that scold a witch? The man of law
Whose honeyed hopes the credulous client draws,
(As bees by tinkling basins) to swarm to him,
From his own hive, to work the wax in his;
He is no witch, not he.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: But these men-witches
Are not in trading with hell's merchandise,
Like such as you are, that for a word, a look,
Denial of a coal of fire, kill men,
Children and cattle.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Tell them, sir, that do so:
Am I accused for such an one?

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Yes, 'twill be sworn.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Dare any swear I ever tempted maiden
With golden hooks flung at her chastity,
To come and lose her honour? and being lost,
To pay not a denier for't? Some slaves have done it.
Men-witches can without the fangs of law,
Drawing once one drop of blood, put counterfeit pieces
Away for true gold.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: By one thing she speaks,
I know now she's a witch, and dare no longer
Hold conference with the fury.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Let's then away:
Old woman, mend thy life, get home and pray.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: For his confusion. [enter dog.]my dear tomboy welcome.
sp.l: I am torn in pieces by a pack of curs
Clapped all upon me, and for want of thee:
Comfort me: thou shalt have the teat anon.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Bow wow: I'll have it now.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: I am dried up
With cursing and with madness; and have yet
No blood to moisten these sweet lips of thine.
Stand on thy hind-legs up. Kiss me, my Tommy,
And rub away some wrinkles on my brow,
by making my old ribs to shrug for joy
Of thy fine tricks. What hast thou done? Let's tickle.
Hast thou struck the horse lame as I bid thee?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Yes, and nipped the sucking-child.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Ho, ho, my dainty,
My little pearl. No lady loves her hound,
Monkey, or parakeet, as I do thee.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: The maid has been churning butter nine hours; but it shall not come.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Let 'em eat cheese and choke.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: I had rare sport
Among the clowns i'th' morris.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: I could dance
Out of my skin to hear thee. But my curl-pate,
That jade, that foul-tongued whore, Nan Ratcliff,
Who for a little soap licked by my sow,
Struck, and almost had lamed it; did not I charge thee,
To pinch that quean to th' heart?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Bow, wow, wow: look here else.

sp.speaker: Ratc.
sp.p: See, see, see; the man i'th' moon has built a new windmill, and what running there's from all quarters of the city to learn the art of grinding!

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Ho, ho, ho! I thank thee, my sweet mongrel.

sp.speaker: Ratc.
sp.p: Hoyda! apox of the devil's false hopper! all the golden meal runs into the rich knave's purses, and the poor have nothing but bran. Hey derry down! Are not you mother Sawyer?

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: No, I am a lawyer.

sp.speaker: Ratc.
sp.p: Art thou? I prithee let me scratch thy face; for thy pen has flayed off a great many men's skins. You'll have brave doings in the vacation; for knaves and fools are at variance in every village. I'll sue mother Sawyer, and her own sow shall give in evidence against her.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Touch her.

sp.speaker: Ratc.
sp.p: O my ribs are made of a paynd hose, and they break. There's a Lancashire hornpipe in my throat: hark how it tickles it, with doodle, doodle, doodle, doodle. Welcome sergeants: welcome devil. Hands, hands; hold hands, and dance around, around, around.
sp.stage: Enter old banks, his son the clown, old Ratcliff, country-fellows.

sp.speaker: O. Ratc.
sp.l: She's here; alas, my poor wife is here.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.p: Catch her fast, and have her into some close chamber: do, for she's as many wives are, stark mad.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: The witch, mother Sawyer, the witch, the devil. [Car. her off.

sp.speaker: O. Ratc.
sp.l: O my dear wife! help, sirs!

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.l: You see your work, mother Bumby.

sp.speaker: Saw.
sp.l: My work? should she and all you here run mad, is the work mine?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: No, on my conscience, she would not hurt a devil of two years old.
sp.stage: Enter old Ratcliff, and the rest.
sp.l: How now? what's become of her?

sp.speaker: O. Ratc.
sp.p: Nothing: she's become nothing, but the miserable trunk of a wretched woman. We were in her hands as reeds in a mighty tempest: spite of our strengths, away she broke; and nothing in her mouth being heard, but the devil, the witch, the witch, the devil; she beat out her own brains, and so died.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: It's any man's case, be he never so wise, to die when his brains go a woolgathering.

sp.speaker: O. banks.
sp.p: Masters, be ruled by me; let's all to a justice. Hag, thou hast done this, and thou shalt answer it.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Banks, I defy thee.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.p: Get a warrant first to examine her, than ship her to Newgate: here's enough, if all her other villainies were pardoned, to burn her for a witch. You have a spirit, they say, comes to you in the likeness of a dog; we shall see your cur at one time or other: if we do, unless it be the devil himself, he shall go howling to the goal in one chain, and thou in another.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Be hanged thou in a third, and do thy worst.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: How, father? you send the poor dumb thing howling to th'goal? He that makes him howl, makes me roar.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.l: Why, foolish boy, dost thou know him?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: No matter, if I do or not. He's bailable I am sure by law. But if the dog's word will not be taken, mine shall.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.l: Thou bail for a dog?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Yes, or a bitch either, being my friend. I'll lie by the heels myself, before Puppison shall: his dog-days are not come yet, I hope.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.l: What manner of dog is it? didst ever see him?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
See him? yes, and given him a bone to gnaw twenty times. The dog is no court foisting hound, that fills his belly
full by base wagging his tail; neither is it a citizen's water-spaniel, enticing his master to go ducking twice or thrice a week, whilst his wife makes ducks and drakes at home: this is no paris-garden bandog neither, that keeps a bough, wow, woughing, to have butchers bring their curs thither; and when all comes to all, they run away like sheep: neither is this the black dog of Newgate.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.l: No, goodman son-fool, but the dog of hellgate.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I say, goodman father-fool, it's a lie.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: He's bewitched.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: A gross lie as big as myself. The devil in st. Dunstan's will as soon drink with this poor cur, as with any temple-bar-laundress, that washes and wrings lawyers.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Bow, wow, wow, wow.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: O the dog's here, the dog's here.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.l: It was the voice of a dog.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: The voice of a dog? if that voice were a dog's, what voice had my mother? so am I a dog: bough, wow, wow: it was I that barked so, father, to make coxcombs of these clowns.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.p: However, we'll be coxcombed no longer: away therefore to th' justice for a warrant; and then, gammer Gurton, have at your needle of witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: And prick thine own eyes out. Go, peevish fools.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Ningle, you had like to have spoiled all with your boughings. I was glad to put 'em off with one of my dog-tricks, on a sudden, I am bewitched, little cost-me-nought, to love thee — a pox, that Morrice makes me spit in thy mouth. I dare not stay. Farewell, ningle; you whoreson dogs-nose. Farewell witch.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Bow, wow, wow, wow.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: Mind him not, he's not worth thy worrying: run at a fairer game: that foul-mouthed knight, scurvy sir Arthur, fly at him, my Tommy; and pluck out's throat.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: No, there a dog already biting's conscience.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: That's a sure bloodhound. Come, let's home and play.
Our black work ended, we'll make holiday.

sp.stage: Enter Katherine: a bed thrust forth, on it Frank in a slumber.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Brother, brother! So sound asleep ? that's well.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: No, not I, sister: he that's wounded here,
As I am; (All my other hurts are bitings
Of a poor flea) but he that here once bleeds,
Is maimed incurably.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: My good sweet brother,
(For now my sister must grow up in you)
Though her loss strikes you through, and that I feel
The blow as deep, I pray thee be not cruel
To kill me too, by seeing you cast away
In your own helpless sorrow. Good love, sit up:
And if you can give physic to yourself,
I shall be well.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I'll do my best.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: I thank you. What do you look about for?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Nothing, nothing; but I was thinking, sister.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Dear heart, what?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Who but a fool would thus be bound to a bed,
Having this room to walk in?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Why do you talk so? would you were fast asleep.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: No, no, I'm not idle:
But here's my meaning: being robbed as I am,
Why should my soul, which married was to hers,
Live in divorce, and not fly after her?
Why should not I walk hand in hand with death
To find my love out?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: That were well, indeed.
Your time being come, when death is sent to call you,
No doubt you shall meet her.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Why should not I go without calling?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Yes, brother, so you might, were there no place
To go to when you're gone, but only this.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Troth, sister, thou sayst true:
For when a man has been an hundred years,
hard travelling o'er the tottering bridge of age,
He's not the thousand part upon his way.
All life is but a wand'ring to find home:
When we are gone, we are there. Happy were man,
Could here his voyage end; he should not then
Answer how well or ill he steered his soul,
By heaven's or by hell's compass; how he put in
(Losing blessed goodness shore) at such a sin;
Nor how life's dear provision he has spent:
Nor how far he in's navigation went
Beyond commission. This were a fine reign,
To do ill, and not hear of it again.
Yet then were man more wretched than a beast:
For, sister, our dead pay is sure the best.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: 'Tis so, the best or worst. And I wish heaven
To pay (And so I know it will) that traitor,
That devil Somerton (Who stood in mine eye
Once as an angel) home to his deservings.
What villain but himself, once loving me,
With Warbeck's soul would pawn his own to hell,
To be revenged on my poor sister?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Slaves! A pair of merciless slaves!
Speak no more of them.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I think this talking hurts you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Does me no good, I'm sure,
I pay for't everywhere.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: I have done then.
Eat, if you cannot sleep: you have these two days
Not tasted any food. Jane, is it ready?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: What's ready? what's ready?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: I have made ready a rosted chicken for you.
Sweet, wilt thou eat?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: A pretty stomach on a sudden — yes —
There's one in the house can play upon a lute:
Good girl, let's hear him too.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: You shall, dear brother.
Would I were a musician, you should hear
How I would feast your ear.
Stay, mend your pillow, and raise you higher.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I am up too high: am I not, sister, now?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: No, no; 'tis well: fall to, fall to. A knife: here's never a knife, brother, I'll look out yours.
sp.stage: Enter dog, shrugging as it were for joy, and dances.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sister, oh sister, I am ill upon a sudden; and can eat nothing.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: In very deed you shall. The want of food makes you so faint. Ha! here's none in your pocket. I'll go fetch a knife.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Will you? 'tis well, all's well.
sp.stage: [she gone, he searches first one, then the other pocket-knife found. Dog runs off. He lies on one side: the spirit of Susan his second wife comes to the bedside. He stares at it; and turning to the other side, it's there too. In the mean time, Winnifride as a page comes in, stands at his beds-feet sadly: he frighted, sits upright. The spirit vanishes.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: A lost creature.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: So am I too.

sp.speaker: Win?
sp.l: Ah, my she-page!

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: For your sake I put on a shape that's false; yet do I wear a heart true to you as your own.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Would mine and thine were fellows in one house. Kneel by me here: on this side now? How dar'st thou come to mock me on both sides of my bed?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But just now: outface me, stare upon me with strange postures: turn my soul wild by a face in which were drawn a thousand ghosts leaped newly from their graves, to pluck me into a winding-sheet.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Believe it, I came no nearer to you than you place, at your beds-feet; and of the house had leave, calling myself your horseboy, in to come, and visit my sick master.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Then 'twas my fancy. Some windmill in my brains for want of sleep.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Would I might never sleep, so you could rest.
But you have plucked a thunder on your head.
Whose noise cannot cease suddenly: why should you
Dance at the wedding of a second wife?
When scarce the music which you heard at mine
Had ta'en a farewell of you. O this was ill!
And they who thus can give both hands away,
In th' end shall want their best limbs.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Winifrid, the chamber door fast?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Sit thee then down;
And when thou'st heard me speak, melt into tears:
Yet I to save those eyes of thine from weeping,
Being to write a story of us two,
In stead of ink, dipped my sad pen in blood.
When of thee I took leave, I went abroad
Only for pillage, as a freebooter,
What gold soe'er I got, to make it thine.
To please a father, I have heaven displeased.
Striving to cast two wedding rings in one,
Through my bad workmanship I now have none.
I have lost her and thee.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I know she's dead: but you have me still.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Nay, her this hand murdered; and so I lose thee too.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: O me!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Be quiet, for thou my evidence art,
Jury and judge: sit quiet, and I'll tell all.
sp.stage: As they whisper, enter at one end o'th' stage old Carter and Katharine, dog at th' other, pawing softly at Frank.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I have run madding up and down to find you, being laden with the heaviest news that ever poor daughter carried.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Why? is the boy dead?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Dead, sir! O father, we are cozened: you are told the murderer sings in prison, and he laughs here.
sp.l: This villain killed my sister: see else, see,
A bloody knife in's pocket.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Bless me, patience!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: The knife, the knife, the knife!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: What knife?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: To cut my chicken up, my chicken; be you my carver, father.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: That I will.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: How the devil steels our brows after doing ill!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: My stomach and my sight are taken from me; all is not well within me.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: I believe thee, boy: I that have seen so many moons clap their horns on other men's foreheads to strike them sick, yet mine to scape, and be well! I that never cast away a fee upon urinals, but am as sound as an honest man's conscience when he's dying, I should cry out as thou dost, all is not well within me, felt I but the bag of thy imposthumes. Ah poor villain! Ah my wounded rascal! all my grief is, I have now small hope of thee.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Do the surgeons say, my wounds are dangerous then?

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Ye, yes, and there's no way with thee but one.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Would he were here to open them.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: I'll go to fetch him: I'll make an holiday to see thee as I wish.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: A wondrous kind old man.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Your sins the blacker, so to abuse his goodness. Master, how do you?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Pretty well now, boy: I have such odd qualms come cross my stomach! I'll fall too: boy, cut me.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: You have cut me, I'm sure, a leg or wing, sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No, no, no: a wing? would I had wings but to soar up you tower: but here's a clog that hinders me. What's that?

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: That? what? O now I see her; 'tis a young wench, my daughter, sirrah, sick to the death: and hearing thee to be an excellent rascal for letting blood, she looks out at a casement, and cries, help, help, stay that man; him I must have, or none.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: For pity's sake, remove her: see, she stares with one broad open eye still in my face.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: Thou puttest both hers out, like a villain as thou art; yet see, she is willing to lend thee one again to find out the murderer, and that's thyself.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Old man, thou liest.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: So shalt thou i'th' goal. Run for officers.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
O thou merciless slave! she was (Though yet above ground) in her grave to me, but thou hast torn it up again. Mine eyes too
much drowned, now must feel more rain.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Fetch officers.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: For whom?

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: For thee, sirrah, sirrah: some knives have foolish posies upon them, but thine has a villainous one; look, oh! it is enameled with the heartblood of thy hated wife, my beloved daughter. What sayest thou to this evidence? is't not sharp? does't not strike home? thou canst not answer honestly, and without a trembling heart, to this one point, this terrible bloody point.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I beseech you, sir, strike him no more; you see he's dead already.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: O, sir! you held his horses, you are as arrant a rogue as he: up, go you too.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: As you're a man, throw not upon that woman your loads of tyranny, for she's innocent.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: How? how? A woman? is't grown to a fashion for women in all countries to wear the breeches?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I am not as my disguise speaks me, sir, his page; but his first only wife, his lawful wife.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: How? how? more fire i'th' bedstraw?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: The wrongs which singly fell on your daughter, on me are multiplied: she lost a life, but I, an husband and myself must lose, if you call him to a bar for what he has done.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: He has done it then?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis confessed to me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Dost thou betray me?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: O pardon me, dear heart! I am mad to lose thee, and know not what I speak: but if thou didst, I must arraign this father for two sins, adultery and murder.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Sir, they are come.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: Arraign me for what thou wilt, all Middlesex knows me better for an honest man, than the middle of a market place knows thee for an honest woman: rise, sirrah, and don your tacklings, rig yourself for the gallows, or I'll carry thee thither on my back: your trull shall to th' goal go with you; there be as fine Newgate birds as she, that can draw him in. Pox on's wounds.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I have served thee, and my wages now are paid, yet my worst punishment shall, I hope, be stayed.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Still wronged by every slave? and not a dog
Bark in his dame's defence? I am called witch,
Yet am myself bewitched from doing harm.
Have I given up myself to thy black lust
Thus to be scorned? not see me in three days?
I'm lost without my Tomalin: prithee come,
Revenge to me is sweeter far than life;
Thou art my raven, on whose coal-black wings
Revenge comes flying to me: oh my best love!
I am on fire, (Even in the midst of ice)
Raking my blood up, till my shrunk knees feel
Thy curled head leaning on them. Come then, my darling,
If in the air thou hoverest, fall upon me
In some dark cloud; and as I oft have seen
Dragons and serpents in the elements,
Appear thou now so to me. Art thou i'th' sea?
Muster up all the monsters from the deep,
And be the ugliest of them: so that my bulch
Show but his swarth cheek to me, let earth cleave,
And break from hell, I care not: could I run
Like a swift powder-mine beneath the world,
Up would I blow it, all to find out thee,
Though I lay ruined in it. Not yet come!
I must then fall to my old prayer:
Sanctibiceter nomem tuum.
Not yet come! worrying of wolves, biting of mad dogs, the manges and the —

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: How now! whom art thou cursing?

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: Thee. Ha! no, 'tis my black cur I am cursing, for not attending ▪ on me.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: I am that cur.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Thou liest: hence, come not nigh me.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Baugh, waugh.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: Why dost thou thus appear to me in white, as if thou wert the ghost of my dear love?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: I am dogged, list not to tell thee, yet to torment thee: my whiteness puts thee in mind of thy winding sweet.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Am I near death?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Yes, if the dog of hell be near thee. When the devil comes to thee as a lamb, have at thy throat.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Off, cur.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: He has the back of a sheep, but the belly of an otter: devours by sea and land. Why am I in white? didst thou not pray to me?

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: Yes, thou dissembling hellhound: why now in white more than at other times?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Be blasted with the news; whiteness is day's footboy, a forerunner to light, which shows thy old riveled face: villains are stripped naked, the witch must be beaten out of her cockpit.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Must she? she shall not; thou art a lying spirit:
Why to mine eyes art thou a flag of truce?
I am at peace with none; 'tis the black colour
Or none, which I fight under: I do not like
Thy puritan-paleness: glowing furnaces
Are far more hot than they which flame outright.
If thou my old dog art, go and bite such as I shall set thee on.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: I will not.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: I'll sell myself to twenty thousand fiends, to have thee torn in pieces then.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Thou canst not: thou art so ripe to fall into hell, that no note of my kennel will so much as bark at him that hangs thee.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: I shall run mad.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Do so, thy time is come, to curse, and rave and die.
The glass of thy sins is full, and it must run out at gallows.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: It cannot, ugly cur, I'll confess nothing;
And not confessing, who dare come and swear
Have bewitched them? I'll not confess one mouthful.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Choose, and be hanged or burned.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: Spite of the devil and thee, I'll muzzle up my tongue from telling tales.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Spite of thee and the devil, thou'lt be condemned.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Yes, when?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: And ere the executioner catch thee full in's claws, thou'lt confess all.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Out dog!

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Out witch! Thy trial is at hand:
Our prey being had, the devil does laughing stand.
sp.stage: The dog stands aloof. Enter old banks, Ratchiff, and countrymen.

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.l: She's here; attach her: witch, you must go with us.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Whither? to hell?

sp.speaker: O. Bank.
sp.p: No, no, no, old crone; your mittimus shall be made thither, but your own jailors shall receive you. Away with her.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: My Tommie! my sweet tomboy! O thou dog! dost thou now fly to thy kennel and forsake me? Plagues and consumptions —

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha!
Let not the world, witches or devils condemn,
They follow us, and then we follow them.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I would fain meet with mine ingle once more; he has had a claw amongst they: my rival that loved my wench, is like to be hanged like an innocent; a kind cur, where he takes; but where he takes not, a dogged rascal. I know the villain loves me: no. [barks.] Art thou there? that's Tom's voice, but 'tis not he: this is a dog of another hair: this? bark and not speak to me? not Tom then: there's as much difference betwixt Tom and this, as betwixt white and black.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Hast thou forgotten me?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: That's Tom again: prithee ningle speak, is thy name Tom?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: While I served my old dame Sawyer, 'twas: I'm gone from her now.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Gone? away with the witch then too: she'll never thrive if thou leavest her; she knows no more how to kill a cow, or a horse, or a sow, without thee, than she does to kill a goose.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: No, she has done killing now, but must be killed for what she has done: she's shortly to be hanged.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Is she? in my conscience if she be, 'tis thou hast brought her to the gallows, Tom.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Right: I served her to that purpose, 'twas part of my wages.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: This was no honest servant's part, by your leave Tom: this remember, I pray you, between you and I; I entertained you ever as a dog, not as a devil.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: True; and so I used thee doggedly, not devilishly.
I have deluded thee for sport to laugh at.
The wench thou seekest after, thou never spak'st with,
But a spirit in her form, habit and likeness. Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I do not then wonder at the change of your garments, if you can enter into shapes of women too.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Any shape, to blind such silly eyes as thine; but chiefly those course creatures, dog or cat, hare, ferret, frog, toad.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Louse or flea?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Any poor vermin.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: It seems you devils have poor thin souls, that you can bestow yourselves in such small bodies: but pray you Tom, one question at parting, I think I shall never see you more; where do you borrow those bodies that are none of your own? the garmentshape you may hire at brokers.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Why wouldst thou know that? fool, it avails thee not.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Only for my mind's sake, Tom, and to tell some of my friends.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: I'll thus much tell thee: thou never art so distant
From an evil spirit, but that thy oaths,
Curses and blasphemies pull him to thine elbow:
Thou never tellst a lie, but that a devil
Is within hearing it; thy evil purposes
Are ever haunted; but when they come to act,
As thy tongue slandering, bearing false witness.
Thy hand stabbing, stealing, cozening, cheating,
He's then within thee: thou play'st, he bets upon thy part;
Although thou lose, yet he will gain by thee.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: I? than he comes in the shape of a rook.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: The old cadaver of some self-strangled wretch
We sometimes borrow, and appear humane.
The carcase of some disease-slain strumpet,
We varnish fresh, and wear as her first beauty.
Didst never hear? if not, it has been done.
An hot luxurious lecher in his twines,
When he has thought to clip his dalliance,
There has provided been for his embrace
A fine hot flaming devil in her place.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Yes, I am partly a witness to this, but I never could embrace her: I thank thee for that, Tom; well, again I thank thee, Tom, for all this counsel, without a fee too; there's few lawyers of thy mind now: certainly Tom, I begin to pity thee.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Pity me? for what?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Were it not possible for thee to become an honest dog yet? 'tis a base life that you lead, Tom, to serve witches, to kill innocent children, to kill harmless cattle, to stroy corn and fruit, etc. 'twere better yet to be a butcher, and kill for yourself.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Why? these are all my delights, my pleasures, fool.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Or Tom, if you could give your mind to ducking, I know you can swim, fetch and carry, some shopkeeper in London would take great delight in you, and be a tender master over you: or if you have a mind to the game, either at bull or bear, I think I could prefer you to Mal-cutpurse.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Ha, ha! I should kill all the game, bulls, bears, dogs, and all, not a cub to be left.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: You could do, Tom, but you must play fair, you should be staved off else: or if your stomach did better like to serve in some noble man's, knights or gentleman's kitchen, if you could brook the wheel, and turn the spit, your labour could not be much; when they have roast-meat, that's but once or twice in the week at most, here you might lick you own toes very well: or if you could translate yourself into a lady's arming-puppy, there you might lick sweet lips, and do many pretty offices; but to creep under an old witches coats, and suck like a great puppy, fie upon't! I have heard beastly things of you, Tom.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Ha, ha! The worse thou heardst of me, the better 'tis.
Shall I serve thee, fool, at the selfsame rate?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: No, I'll see thee hanged, thou shalt be damned first; I know thy qualities too well, I'll give no suck to such whelps; therefore henceforth I defy thee; out and avaunt.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Nor will I serve for such a silly soul.
I am for greatness now, corrupted greatness;
There I'll shug in, and get a noble countenance:
Serve some Briarean footcloth-strider,
That has an hundred hands to catch at bribes,
But not a finger's nail of charity.
Such, like the dragon's tail, shall pull down hundreds
To drop and sink with him: I'll stretch myself,
And draw this bulk small as a silver-wire,
Enter at the least poor tobacco fume
Can make a breach for: hence silly fool,
I scorn to prey on such an atom soul.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Come out, come out, you cur; I will beat thee out of the bounds of Edmonton, and tomorrow we go in procession, and after thou shalt never come in again: if thou goest to London, I'll make thee go about by Tyburn, stealing in by thieving lane: if thou canst rub thy shoulder against a lawyer's gown, as thou passest by Westminster-hall, do; if not, to the stairs amongst the bandogs, take water, and the devil go with thee.
sp.stage: Enter justice, sir Arthur, Warbeck, Carter, Kate.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Sir Arthur, though the bench hath mildly censured your errors, yet you have indeed been the instrument that wrought all their misfortunes: I would wish you paid down your fine speedily and willingly.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: I'll need no urging to it.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: If you should, 'twere a shame to you; for if I should speak my conscience, you are worthier to be hanged of the two, all things considered; and now make what you can of it: but I am glad these gentlemen are freed.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: We knew our innocence.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: And therefore feared it not.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: But I am glad that I have you safe.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: How now! what noise is that?

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: Young Frank is going the wrong way: alas, poor youth! now I begin to pity him.
sp.stage: Enter Y. Thorney and holberts. Enter as to see the execution, o. Carter, o. Thorney, Katharine, Winnifride weeping.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: Here let our sorrows wait him: to press nearer
The place of his sad death, some apprehensions
may tempt our grief too much, at height already.
Daughter, be comforted.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Comfort and I
Are too far separated to be joined
But in eternity. I share too much of him that's going thither.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Poor woman, 'twas not thy fault: I grieve to see
Thee weep for him that hath my pity too.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: My fault was lust, my punishment was shame;
Yet I am happy that my soul is free
Both from consent, foreknowledge and intent
Of any murder, but of mine own honour.
Restored again by a fair satisfaction, and since not to be wounded.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.p: Daughter, grieve not for what necessity forceth; rather resolve to conquer it with patience. Alas, she faints!

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: My griefs are strong upon me: my weakness scarce can bear them.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Away with her! hang her, witch!
sp.stage: Enter sawyes to execution, officers with holberts, countrypeople.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: The witch, that instrument of mischief! did not she witch the devil into my son-in-law, when he killed my poor daughter? do you hear, mother Sawyer?

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: What would you have? cannot a poor old woman have your leave to die without vexation?

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: Did not you bewitch Frank to kill his wife? he could never have don't without the devil.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Who doubts it? but is every devil mine?
Would I had one now whom I might command
To tear you all in pieces: Tom would have don't before he left me.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Thou didst bewitch Anne Ratcliff to kill herself.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.p: Churl, thou liest; I never did her hurt: would you were all as near your ends as I am, that gave evidence against me for it.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: I'll be sworn, Mr. Carter, she bewitched gammer Washbowl's sow, to cast her pigs a day before she would have farrowed; et they were sent up to London, and sold for as good Westminster dog-pigs, at Bartholomew fair, as ever great bellied alewife longed for.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: These dogs will mad me: I was well resolved
to die in my repentance; though 'tis true.
I would live longer if I might: yet since
I cannot, pray torment me not; my conscience
Is settled as it shall be, all take heed
How they believe the devil, at last he'll cheat you.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Thou'dst best confess all truly.

sp.speaker: Sawy.
sp.l: Yet again?
Have I scarce breath enough to say my prayers?
And would you force me to spend that in bawling?
Bear witness, I repent all former evil ▪
There is no damned conjurer like the devil.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Away with her, away!
sp.stage: Enter Frank to execution, officers, justice, sir Arthur. Warbeck, Somerton.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: Here's the sad object which I yet must meet
With hope of comfort, if a repentant end
Make him more happy than misfortune would
Suffer him here to be.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Good sire, turn from me;
You will revive affliction almost killed
With my continual sorrow.

sp.speaker: O Thor.
sp.l: O Frank, Frank!
Would I had sunk in mine own wants, or died
But one bare minute ere thy fault was acted.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: To look upon your sorrows, executes me before my execution.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Let me pray you, sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Thou much wronged woman, I must sigh for thee,
As he that's only loath to leave the world,
For that he leaves thee in it unprovided,
Unfriended; and for me to beg a pity
From any man to thee when I am gone,
Is more than I can hope; nor to say truth,
Have I deserved it: but there is a payment
Belongs to goodness from the great exchequer
Above, it will not fail thee, Winifrid;
Be that thy comfort.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: Let it be thine too,
Untimely lost young man.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: He is not lost,
Who bears his peace within him: had I spun
My web of life out at full length, and dreamed
Away my many years in lusts, in surfeits,
murders of reputations, gallant fins
Commended or approved; then though I had
Died easily, as great and rich men do,
Upon my own bed, not compelled by justice,
You might have mourned for me indeed; my miseries
Had been as everlasting, as remediless:
But now the law hath not arraigned, condemned
With greater rigour my unhappy fact,
Than I myself have every little sin
My memory can reckon from my childhood:
A court hath been kept here, where I am found
Guilty; the difference is, my impartial judge
Is much more gracious than my faults
Are monstrous to be named; yet they are monstrous.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: Here's comfort in this penitence.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: It speaks
How truly you are reconciled, and quickens
My dying comfort, that was near expiring
With my last breath: now this repentance makes thee
As white as innocence; and my first sin with thee,
Since which I knew none like it, by my sorrow,
Is clearly cancelled: might our souls together
Climb to the height of their eternity,
And there enjoy what earth denied us, happiness:
But since I must survive, and be the monument
Of thy loved memory, I will preserve it
With a religious care, and pay thy ashes
A widow's duty, calling that end best,
Which though it stain the name, makes the soul blessed

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Give me thy hand, poor woman: do not weep:
Farewell. Thou dost forgive me?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: 'Tis my part
To use that language

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: O that my example
Might teach the world hereafter what a curse
Hangs on their heads, who rather choose to marry
A goodly portion, than a dower of virtues!
Are you there, gentlemen? there is not one
Amongst you whom I have not wronged: you most;
Robbed you of a daughter; but she is
In heaven; and I must suffer for it willingly.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Ay, ay, she's in heaven, and I am glad to see
Thee so well prepared to follow her:
I forgive thee with all my heart; if thou
Hadst not had ill counsel, thou wouldst not have
Done as thou didst: the more shame for them.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Spare your excuse to me, I do conceive
What you would speak: I would you could as easily
Make satisfaction to the law, as to my wrongs.
I am sorry for you.

sp.speaker: Warb.
sp.l: And so am I, and heartily forgive you.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I will pray for you, for her sake, who, I am sure, did love you dear.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.p: Let us part friendly too: I am ashamed of my part in thy wrongs.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You are all merciful, and send me to my grave in peace. Sir Arthur, heavens send you a new heart. Lastly to you, sir; and though I have deserved not to be called your son, yet give me leave upon my knees, to beg a blessing.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.l: Take it: let me wet thy cheeks with the last
Tears my griefs have left me. O Frank, Frank, Frank!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Let me beseech you, gentlemen, to
Comfort my old father; keep him with ye;
Love this distressed widow; and as often
As you remember what a graceless man
I was, remember likewise that these are
Both free, both worthy of a better fate,
Than such a son or husband as I have been.
All help me with your prayers. On, on, 'tis just
That law should purge the guilt of blood and lust.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: Go thy ways: I did not think to have shed one tear for thee, but thou hast made me water my plants spite of my heart. M. Thorney, cheer up, man; whilst I can stand by you, you shall not want help to keep you from falling. We have lost our children both on's the wrong way, but we cannot help it: better or worse, 'tis now as 'tis.

sp.speaker: O. Thor.
sp.p: I thank you, sir, you are more kind than I have cause to hope or look for.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Mr. Somerton, is Kate yours or no?

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: We are agreed,

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And, but my faith is passed, I should fear to be married husbands are so cruelly unkind: excuse me that I am thus troubled.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Thou shalt have no cause.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Take comfort mistress Winifrid. Sir Arthur,
For his abuse to you, and to your husband,
Is by the bench enjoined to pay you down
A thousand marks.

sp.speaker: Sir Art.
sp.l: Which I will soon discharge.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis too great a sum to be employed upon my funeral.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: Come, come, if luck had served, sir Arthur, and every man had his due, somebody might have tottered ere this, without paying fines: like it as you list. Come to me Winifrid, shalt be well come: make much of her, Kate, I charge you: I do not think but she's a good wench, and hath has wrong as well as we. So let 'Every man home to Edmonton with heavy hearts, yet as merry a we can, though not as we would.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Join friends in sorrow; make of all the best:
Harms past may be lamented, not redressed.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I am a widow still, and must not sort
A second choice, without a good report;
Which though some widows find, and few deserve,
Yet I dare not presume, but will not swerve
From modest hopes. All noble tongues are free;
The gentle may speak one kind word for me.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
